title: Airplane Delays
text:
1 Introduction
On average, flight delays cost the U.S. economy $285 million and $580 million per day (FAA). It also affects 236 million travellers, almost 1 in 4 passengers, each year (Airhelp). To understand where and why these delays occur, we will analyse the on-time statistics and delay causes of U.S. domestic flights from January to June 2025. Our analysis will answer two key questions: (1) Do U.S. airports fall into distinct operational delay profiles, and what drives the differences between those profiles? (2) Which delay causes the greatest cost across the system? By examining five delay categories across major airlines and airports, we can identify systemic patterns as well as airport-specific challenges that could guide future operational improvements.

title: 2  Data
text:
2.1 Description
This data comes from the United States Department of Transportation’s Bureau of Transportation Statistics and contains information on flight delays and cancellations for domestic flights in the first six months of 2025. In that time period, there were a total of 11,404 delayed operations by 21 airlines at 370 airports.
Each observation represents aggregated monthly statistics for a specific airport-airline combination (i.e. HOU-Southwest-January or IAD-Delta-May). There are 21 variables representing flight volumes, delay counts, delay durations, cancellations and diversions. A flight is considered delayed if it arrives more than 15 minutes after its scheduled time.
Key Delay Categories (each measured in both count and minutes):
It is important to note that the delay time and delay count metrics capture different aspects of performance; an airport could have many short delays (high count, low time) or a few very long delays (low count, high time), so both dimensions must be considered in the analysis. Additionally, because airports and airlines vary significantly in size, performance comparisons will need to be normalised by the total number of incoming flights to create meaningful per-flight delay rates.

title: 2  Data
text:
Carrier delays: airline-controlled issues (maintenance, crew, baggage) 
Weather delays: extreme weather conditions
NAS delays: National Airspace System issues (air traffic control, non-extreme weather, high volume) 
Security delays 
Late aircraft delays

title: 2  Data
text:
2.2 Missing value analysis


Code
df <- read_csv("Airline_Delay_Cause.csv")
colSums(is.na(df)) |> 
  sort(decreasing = TRUE)




Code
missing_percent <- df %>%
  summarise(across(everything(), ~ mean(is.na(.))*100)) %>%
  pivot_longer(everything(),
               names_to = "variable",
               values_to = "percent_missing")

ggplot(missing_percent, aes(x = reorder(variable, percent_missing), y = percent_missing)) +
  geom_col(fill = "blue") +
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Percent Missing per Variable",
    y = "% Missing"
  )

title: 3  Results
text:
3.1 Q1. How do delay patterns vary across U.S. airports and states, and how are these patterns associated with geography, dominant delay types, and airport traffic volume?
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(GGally)
library(janitor)
library(statebins)
library(ggplot2)

df <- read_csv("Airline_Delay_Cause.csv")
Code
delay_airport <- df |>
  group_by(airport, airport_name) |>
  summarise(
    total_flights = sum(arr_flights, na.rm = TRUE),
    carrier_delay = sum(carrier_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    weather_delay = sum(weather_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    nas_delay = sum(nas_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    security_delay = sum(security_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    late_aircraft_delay = sum(late_aircraft_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  mutate(
    carrier_rate = carrier_delay / total_flights,
    weather_rate = weather_delay / total_flights,
    nas_rate = nas_delay / total_flights,
    security_rate = security_delay / total_flights,
    late_aircraft_rate = late_aircraft_delay / total_flights
  )

delay_cols <- c("carrier_rate", "weather_rate", "nas_rate",
                "security_rate", "late_aircraft_rate")

delay_norm <- delay_airport |>
  mutate(across(all_of(delay_cols), scale))

library(viridis)

delay_cols <- c(
  "carrier_rate",
  "weather_rate",
  "nas_rate",
  "security_rate",
  "late_aircraft_rate"
)
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(GGally)

state_delay <- delay_airport |>
  mutate(
    state = sub(".*, ([A-Z]{2}):.*", "\\1", airport_name),
    region = state.region[match(state, state.abb)]
  ) |>
  group_by(state, region) |>
  summarise(
    carrier_rate = mean(carrier_rate, na.rm = TRUE),
    weather_rate = mean(weather_rate, na.rm = TRUE),
    nas_rate = mean(nas_rate, na.rm = TRUE),
    security_rate = mean(security_rate, na.rm = TRUE),
    late_rate = mean(late_aircraft_rate, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

GGally::ggparcoord(
  data = state_delay,
  columns = 3:7,        # the 5 delay rate columns
  groupColumn = "region",
  scale = "std",        # normalize each axis
  alphaLines = 0.6
) +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set1") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13) +
  labs(
    title = "Parallel Coordinate Plot of State Delay Profiles",
    subtitle = "Lines represent states; Colors represent Census regions",
    x = "Delay Type",
    y = "Standardized Delay Rate",
    color = "Region"
  ) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "right",
    axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)
  )
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(reshape2)
library(viridis)
library(ggplot2)

delay_cols <- c(
  "carrier_rate",
  "weather_rate",
  "nas_rate",
  "security_rate",
  "late_aircraft_rate"
)

corr_mat <- delay_airport |>
  select(all_of(delay_cols)) |>
  cor(use = "pairwise.complete.obs")

corr_df <- melt(corr_mat)
names(corr_df) <- c("DelayType1", "DelayType2", "Correlation")

ggplot(corr_df, aes(x = DelayType1, y = DelayType2, fill = Correlation)) +
  geom_tile(color = "white") +
  scale_fill_distiller(
  palette = "Blues", direction=1) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  labs(
    title = "Correlation Heatmap of Airport Delay Types",
    x = "Delay Type",
    y = "Delay Type",
    fill = "Correlation"
  ) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))
Code
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(ggplot2)

delay_scatter_long <- delay_airport |>
  select(
    airport, total_flights,
    carrier_rate, weather_rate, nas_rate,
    security_rate, late_aircraft_rate
  ) |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = ends_with("_rate"),
    names_to = "delay_type",
    values_to = "delay_rate"
  )

ggplot(delay_scatter_long,
       aes(x = total_flights, y = delay_rate)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5, size = 1.5, color = "blue") +
  scale_x_log10(
    breaks = c(100, 1000, 10000, 100000),
    labels = c("100", "1K", "10K", "100K")
  ) +
  facet_wrap(~ delay_type, scales = "free_y") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 15) +
  labs(
    title = "Airport Size vs Delay Rate by Delay Type",
    x = "Total Flights (Log Scale)",
    y = "Delay Rate (%)"
  )
Code
library(ggalluvial)

state_flow <- delay_airport |>
  mutate(
    state = sub(".*, ([A-Z]{2}):.*", "\\1", airport_name),
    region = state.region[match(state, state.abb)]
  ) |>
  rowwise() |>
  mutate(
    dominant = delay_cols[
      which.max(c_across(all_of(delay_cols)))
    ]
  ) |>
  ungroup() |>
  tidyr::drop_na(region) |>
  group_by(region, dominant) |>
  summarise(count = n(), .groups = "drop")

ggplot(state_flow,
       aes(axis1 = region, axis2 = dominant, y = count)) +
  geom_alluvium(aes(fill = dominant)) +
  geom_stratum() +
  geom_label(aes(label = after_stat(stratum)), stat = "stratum") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Region-to-Dominant Delay Type Flow",
    y = "Number of Airports"
  )
Code
library(sf)
library(tidyverse)

delay_by_state_type <- delay_airport |>
  mutate(state = sub(".*, ([A-Z]{2}):.*", "\\1", airport_name)) |>
  group_by(state) |>
  summarise(
    carrier_delay = sum(carrier_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    weather_delay = sum(weather_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    nas_delay = sum(nas_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    security_delay = sum(security_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    late_aircraft_delay = sum(late_aircraft_delay, na.rm = TRUE),
    total_flights = sum(total_flights, na.rm = TRUE)
  ) |>
  mutate(
    state_full = tolower(state.name[match(state, state.abb)]),
    carrier_rate = carrier_delay / total_flights,
    weather_rate = weather_delay / total_flights,
    nas_rate = nas_delay / total_flights,
    security_rate = security_delay / total_flights,
    late_rate = late_aircraft_delay / total_flights
  )
Code
library(ggplot2)
library(viridis)

delay_long <- delay_by_state_type |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = ends_with("_rate"),
    names_to = "delay_type",
    values_to = "delay_value"
  ) |>
  mutate(
    delay_type = recode(delay_type,
                        carrier_rate = "Carrier",
                        weather_rate = "Weather",
                        nas_rate = "NAS",
                        security_rate = "Security",
                        late_rate = "Late Aircraft")
  )

states_sf <- st_as_sf(maps::map("state", plot = FALSE, fill = TRUE))

plot_data <- left_join(
  states_sf,
  delay_long,
  by = c("ID" = "state_full")
) |>
  mutate(
    state_abb = toupper(state.abb[match(ID, tolower(state.name))]),
    region = state.region[match(state_abb, state.abb)]  
  ) |>
  filter(!is.na(region)) 

delay_types <- plot_data |>
  dplyr::filter(!is.na(delay_type)) |>
  dplyr::pull(delay_type) |>
  unique()

plot_list <- list()

for (dt in delay_types) {
  p <- ggplot(filter(plot_data, delay_type == dt)) +
    geom_sf(aes(fill = delay_value), color = "white", linewidth = 0.2) +
    geom_sf_text(aes(label = state_abb), size = 3, color = "black") +
    scale_fill_viridis_c(direction = -1) +
    theme_void() +
    labs(
      title = paste(dt, "Delay Rate per Flight by State"),
      fill = "Delay per Flight"
    )

  plot_list[[dt]] <- p
}

plot_list


$Carrier










$Weather










$NAS










$Security










$`Late Aircraft`

title: 3  Results
text:
Western states tend to have lower rates cross all delay types, and security delay rate is the smallest, which is shown as distinct cluster around 0.



Security delays shows almost no correlations with other delay type. Weather and carrier rate, and late aircraft and NAS rate are most correlated.



Airport size does not strongly predict overall delay rate. The delay rate varies more in the airports with smaller airport size (around 1k), often including extreme outliers.



Late aircraft delays are more dominant type for most airports nationwide. Carrier delays dominate many airports in the South and West.




Carrier

There are unusual high delays in West Virginia, and parts of Mid-Atlantic states. Most of other states have moderate and consistent delays.

Weather

The delay rates are higher in Midwest and Mountain states. Again, West Virginia has the most extreme delay rate, which aligns with previous delay type.

NAS delays

Overall delays are relatively low. Colorado has relatively high NAS delays, and New Jersey stands out as an outline with very high delay rate.

Security

Security delays are extremely rare in the nation, and again, West Virginia has the highest, extreme value compared to the rest of the states.

Late aircraft delays

Delays are higher in Northeast and part of Midwest (Pennsylvania, West Virginia), while most Western and Southern states have low delay rates.
